questions: Q.1. Who was Nelson Mandela?
answers: Ans. Nelson Mandela was the leader of African National Congress (ANC). He remained in jail for 28 years in South Africa’s most dreaded prison, Robben Island opposing the apartheid regime.

questions: Q.2. Who were called ‘blacks’ in South Africa?
answers: Ans. The native people of South Africa are black in colour, they made up about three-fourth of the population and were called ‘blacks’.

questions: Q.3. How non-whites were treated in South Africa?
answers: Ans. The white rulers treated all non–whites as inferiors. The non-whites did not have voting rights.

questions: Q.4. What was ANC?
answers: Ans. It was African National Congress, an umbrella organisation that led the struggle against the policies of segregation. This included many workers’ unions and the Communist Party.

questions: Q.5. With which rules trust was built between blacks and whites in South Africa?

questions: Q.6. What is this set of basic rules called?
answers: Ans. This set of basic rules is called a ‘Constitution’.

questions: Q.7. What is a ‘Constitution’?
answers: Ans. The Constitution of a country is a set of written rules that are accepted by all the people living together in a country.

questions: Q.8. Why is Constitution considered the Supreme law?
answers: Ans. The Constitution is the supreme law that determines the relationship among people living a territory (called citizens) and also the relationship between the people and the government.

questions: Q.9. How difficult it was for India to frame a constitution for united India after independence?
answers: Ans. At that time the people of India were emerging from the status of subjects to that of citizens. The country was born through a partition on the religious basis. This was a traumatic experience for the people of India and Pakistan.

questions: Q.10. Who was the first one to draft a constitution for India?
answers: Ans. In 1928, Motilal Nehru and eight other Congress leaders drafted a constitution for India.

questions: Q.11. What resolution was made in 1931, Karachi session?
answers: Ans. In 1931, the resolution at the Karachi session of the Indian National Congress dealt on how independent India’s constitution should look like.

questions: Q.12. What was ‘Constituent Assembly’?
answers: Ans. The drafting of the document called the ‘constitution’ was done by an assembly of elected representatives called the Constituent Assembly.

questions: Q.13. In which manner Constituent Assembly worked?
answers: Ans. The Constituent Assembly worked in a systematic, open and consensual manner.

questions: Q.14. Why was a drafting committee formulated? Who was its Chairman?
answers: Ans. The drafting Committee was formed to prepare a draft of the constitution for discussion. Its Chairman was Dr. B.R. Ambedkar.

questions: Q.15. Who was the Chairman of the Constituent Assembly?
answers: Ans. Dr. Rajendra Prasad was the Chairman of the Constituent Assembly.

questions: Q.16. What features formed the foundation for India’s democracy?
answers: Ans. The Values that inspired and guided the freedom struggle and were then nurtured by it, formed the foundation for India’s democracy.

questions: Q.17. What is Preamble?
answers: Ans. The Preamble is like preface of a book, it is the soul of the Indian Constitution. It gives in brief all the laws and action of the government.

questions: Q.18. What does ‘Sovereign’ mean?
answers: Ans. It means people have supreme right to make decisions on internal as well as external matters. No external power can dictate the government of India.

questions: Q.19. What does ‘Socialist’ in a democratic Constitution mean?
answers: Ans. Wealth is generated socially and should be shared equally by society. Government should try to reduce socio-economic inequalities.

questions: Q.20. What is the meaning of the form ‘Secular’?
answers: Ans. Citizens have complete freedom to follow any religion. But there is no official religion. Government treats all religions, beliefs and practices with equal respect.

questions: Q.21. What does ‘democratic’ mean?
answers: Ans. It is a form of government where people enjoy equal political rights, elect their rulers and hold them accountable.

questions: Q.22. What does ‘Equality’ term mean in the Indian Constitution?
answers: Ans. All are equal before the law. The traditional social inequalities have to be ended. The government should ensure equal opportunities for all.

questions: Q.23. What does the term ‘Fraternity’ signify in the Preamble?
answers: Ans. All of us should behave as if we are members of the same family. No one should treat a fellow citizen as inferior.

questions: Q.24. What are ‘Constitutional Amendments’?
answers: Ans. Provisions are made to incorporate changes from time to time in our constitution. These changes are called ‘Constitutional Amendments’.
